pros:
1. Employee friendly - DB Singapore takes efforts to keep employees happy in terms of benefits and regional activities
2. Mobility is encouraged - But perhaps it will be easier for people who have been with the bank for a longer time to move around easily
cons:
1. Salary disparity - Unless you get promoted or get a good hike when you join, you cannot expect your salary to grow much each year
2. Depending on your role and team structure (especially in Technology roles) you may end up working with peers in other timezones. This will be a overkill especially if you end up with working with counterparts who are further apart from your timezone e.g. USA. 
3. Depending upon the role and team (especially in Technology roles), growing within the organization beyond AVP is extremely difficult as most decision making is done either in Germany or UK. Often you'll see colleagues or senior managers recommending you to move to US, Germany or UK if you want to grow in the organization.
4. Technology adoption rate is low and there are too many red-tape processes that hinder getting things done (especially in Technology)

pros: Working at Deutsche is great fun and learning experience those who step up and grab the opportunity. The amount of exposure you get across various aspect of business is open to all. This is a very people oriented company and does help individuals who deserve it.
cons: One of the challenges in working for Deutsche is the amount of change the organisation goes through, irrespective of the good days or bad. This is very taxing for less flexible employees. Also does not help individuals to plan their career on their own within the organisation. Hence one is always dependent on grabbing the opportunity as an when they show up with very less time to think ahead. This is also not very good for the company as it does find itself stuck with mismatch roles.

review_title: It was a good company to work for. . .
pros: You can learn to navigate a snake pit. Also, could potentially learn to avoid being eaten by piranhas.
cons: Well, the only time that you will get a raise is if you are promoted. The problem is that promotions are incredibly difficult to secure. The easier way to get promoted at DB is to get a job at another company, then come back a year later at a higher corporate rank. There is no governance process for the hiring at a given corporate rank, but if you seek a promotion within the organization, tons and tons of hurdles to overcome. Good luck.

pros: Very dynamic organization- rapid pace of change and development. Very good at innovation. Led by a bunch of smart people specially on the glabal markets side. Good strategy to sustain in the long run.
cons: Highly silo'ed environment- minimal cooperation when working on cross-divisional initiatives. Poor infrastructural and control platforms- chances of a Soc-gen like scenario are not remote. Not a very structured promotion process- possible to get windfall gains from one good year's performance without the ability to sustain that performance in the long run. Low on work-life balance. Center of power largely in Frankfurt, low influence/image iN US.

pros: Good office and decent colleagues overall. You can expect some vicious and political characters in the middle office (Global Sourcing, Technology, Corporate Real Estate and O&T).
cons: Global operating model means that APAC has no power and has to take lead on almost all critical decisions from global leaders. Currently axing staff in APAC where it does not make sense as APAC is the growth region.

pros: - They used to hire great people.
cons:
- Now they treat them badly. There is no incentive. The board is high up trying to boost share price, makings things right. But they forget that people is important.

- Too much politics.

- Management team doesn't understand technology, hence they could only accept what's been presented. The technology and system development is lack of strategic planning, costly and inefficient. 

- No pay increase without a promotion. No bonus. Much more difficult to get a promotion.

pros:
Working with some of the highliest skilled people in the industry with expansion in some of the most interesting markets.

Very diverse staff, client, product and operating platform

Comparatively good staff benefits

Ongoing growth and opportunities particularly in Asia (despite of onsite job cut-downs due to ongoing smart- and outsourcing of processes into low-payment hubs in Manila, Berlin, Mumbai, New Jersey etc)
cons:
Global senior management in Deutsche continues to very much be an old boy's club, chauvinism is omnipresent at this level, and gender discrimination is very common in mid and senior levels and part of the company culture (despite official policies and speeches). Similar discrepancies between official and inofficial company cultural values in many other areas.

As an MD or Dir, be prepared to deal with a comparatively high rate of politics and silo-mentality standing in the way of efficiency and bank-wide cooperation

Experimental minor and major restructurings, which often are short-sighted unaligned measures of pure activism, are ever present. Many things tend to go back to where they were after a certain amount of time - of course, as in many places, going back to former solutions is usually sold as yet another big innovation, not as a strategic mistake being corrected. Low buy-ins into and unspoken boycots of restructuring measures by mid and senior managers as a result.

Recent year cost cutting programs and smartsourcing of jobs result in overall low job morale, resignation and frustration.

review_title: Unfair compensation scheme to junior executives
pros: Well known organisation, good for adding that into your CV for future career advancement
cons: Poor job stability, career stagnation for those who remain, bonus structure is extremely unbalance,  AVP and below are not entitled to individual performance, they are eligible for  regnition award which is only given to a selected few and not tied to individual performance appraisal rating, basic pay doesn't increased unless you are promoted. There is no distinction between one employee with outstanding rating vs the other one who has good rating as the net result is both will get the same group component variable.

review_title: Too big to actually get anything done
pros: There's patches of interesting things and good people, you have to seek them out but they are there. A lot of old dinosaurs though
cons:
Far too big to actually work. You'd think from the outside that an org of this size would be very impressive but when you get inside you realise that just because there's 80,000 people working here, doesn't mean the place is slick and efficient, in fact quite the opposite. 

The technology is also very backward, 5 years behind the last bank I worked at and they seem reluctant ti spend any money to change that.

And don't get me started on "Matrix management" the dumbest thing I ever heard, just means you don't have a manager, everything decided by committee, its just great!!

job_title: Investment Banking Summer Analyst in Singapore
pros:
Deutsche Bank has a structured Internship program that lets you learn and contribute at the same time. You are usually assigned a mentor who will assign you a project for the summer internship. You are given responsibilities you would normally have if you were working at DB which is great. 

Very smart people , very relaxed atmosphere my mentor was great to me even though he was quite senior in the bank so it was nice.
cons: Competitive , friendly rivalry for top spots. I also think that the human resources department is lacking in terms of being co-ordinate in assessing new interns.

pros: Its a great place to work at. Brilliant minds all around you. If you join as an analyst, you go though an almost vertical learning curve. There is really tons to learn. So you have to be sure you are prepared for a career in finance. Every individual in the bank gets a lot of responsibility. Even as an analyst you work in a small team of 4-5 and become an expert in whatever task you have been entrusted with. Its a great place for personal development.
cons: Cutthroat competition. You have to be at the top of your job. No room for error.

review_title: Very difficult place to get anything done!
pros: Met some great people. These folks try their darned best to get stuff done everyday, but were climbing a slippery slope. It was only a matter of time before they threw in the towel.
cons:
Organization is crippled with red-tape, bureaucracy and an unrealistic security setup, that getting any work done takes 10 times what will be considered normal. Innovation is almost impossible as everything has to fit in a predefined standard. There is hardly any leadership to speak of that recognises this and does something about it.

Some of the approval processes make zero sense and more often than not, people get exceptions to get around it. Very frustrating day-to-day work-life!

pros: Team work and the fact that everyone plays a role. You know that your contribution is appreciated and in fact even relied upon. From the humblest of operational staff to the person structuring the deal and the relationship manager at the front line, you learn quickly that you cannot work alone.
cons: Things move extremely slowly which is good if that is how you like them to move. A glacial stately pace however makes for idle hands. If you are in middle management, affairs are usually not within your control.

review_title: Good Benefits, Poor Management and processes
pros: Good benefits, good software deployment processes, good office and facilities, People who have been in the company for a long time and grown to senior positions
cons: Late sitting was common, No scheduled release cycles, Insufficient resources provided to perform work, Micro management, people generally work by escalations

review_title: Not a good time to join
pros: Great people, plenty of project opportunities. Business is very innovative. New Ceo is promising but challenge to overhaul may be too great.
cons: Very fragmented infrastructure. Company grew too quickly. Poor data quality. Overly bureaucratic + slow decision making, so much needed change is very slow and demoralising. Needs to cut costs but does not know how / unable to execute. Overhang of litigation and decision to reduce pay to compensate for this is highly demoralising.

pros:
- Good place to learn new things.
- Global working environment.
- Most of the people are nice and helpful.
cons:
- Lack of advancement opportunities- Managers are only interested in meeting their own KPI' s and not interested in promoting career advancement of their team members. Performance appraisals are just a formality.
-Don't spend much on training to upgrade the skills of the current staff.
-Compensation has been flat.

review_title: Enriching and fulfilling experience with a lot of stuff to learn.
pros: Very prestigious and focus on performance. The bank has a stable growth and compensation and welfare is good. People here are talented and very focused.
cons: A little bit bureaucratic and lower level staff are not willing to voice their ideas or objections to senior management. Sometimes have to work extra hours to finish work.

pros: In most teams across technology and operations, they were a great bunch of people focused on doing their best on the company and supporting cross functions for the greater good. Good support from management locally and globally and great non-work staff interactions for corporate responsibility and staff club events.
cons: It's not the company but some people who make life difficult for the rest.

review_title: Good brand name but middle office divisions can be quite political
pros: Company has a recognized brand name, smart people (at least quite a few), working hours are quite reasonable, internal mobility options are quite good
cons: Bureaucratic and a lot of politics in middle office. average system architecture which leads to lot of manual tasks which are tedious. Which can explain the relatively high attrition in some parts of the bank.

pros: Good benefits, good pay, open culture, good banking frameworks and detailed guidelines, many opportunities to network
cons:
Poor management sometimes: managers don't know how to communicate properly causing stress to employees and some managers are too busy playing politics to do any real work.
Limited chances to learn as functions are all segregated so it can get boring after doing the same thing over and over.

pros:
Excellent health benefits
Good work life balance.  Most people knock off before 7pm
cons:
Compensation is notoriously terrible, to the point of negligible in the recent years of cost cutting.
All the daily work is outsourced to India/ Manila so most of the people spent time on meetings to show case their ''work'', network and rub shoulders, or simply going for tea breaks. Introverts won't make it far here.

pros: Generally friendly people, open culture. Most staff are highly educated and smart people.
cons: Very strong silo culture in the bank, hard to move across to different business divisions. Management is not always honest and will underpay or not promote if employees do not expressly ask for it.

pros:
- Autonomy to manage team and work by middle level manager; no micro management from boss 
- Invested a lot in technology and kept advanced position among banks
- Plenty training opportunities and role rotation
- Clear career path and supported by C level
cons:
- Job security is weaken due to outsource and relocation
- Financial performance is not as good as before

review_title: Deutsche Bank is going through tumultuous times
pros: Staff at Deutsche Bank are generally warm, friendly and collaborative. It's Diversity branding is also fairly strong within the banking industry. Good medical / health benefits and flexi work arrangements.
cons: The organisation is not what it used to be - the culture is a lot more cut throat and staff are getting retrenched quite ruthlessly.

review_title: A good place to work, well respected within the Financial community in troubled times
pros: Promotes good work / life balance , opportunities for international and internal mobility. Looks after staff. Generally happy working at DB.
cons: Hours can be long , but that's a given in the banking profession and to progress you choose to put in the hours.

review_title: DB WEALTH MANAGEMENT EM-Good place to work in terms of new initiatives. However, decision making is not crystal clear.
pros: Opportuntiy to learn new initiatives
cons: Technology and implementation is one of the poorest. Heavily dependent on multiple vendors. Management decisions keep changing every other month.

pros: I as a junior person can work comfortably with managers at director or even MD level . Plus the team is always ready and willing to support whenever you need them .
cons: The lawsuit cases these years and worsening financial environment is tough now for all European banks and especially Deutsche . Also, the company is too big and made the implementation of strategies difficult and changing all the time .

review_title: Good bank that looks out for its employees
pros: Top notch graduate program, ample opportunities to gain training and mentoring, gives juniors responsibility quickly.
cons: Easy to get lost in the huge organisation, management strategy and direction not clearly articulated at times. Political at times, especially in certain teams.

pros:
Decent salary for working hours
Good medical benefits
cons:
Too many to mention all but seriously the worst place to work at if you have to work under my department head.

Department head has very clearly showed differential treatment to newcomers (young fresh graduates) opposed to the older workers. 


No bonus at all for the past years I'm working here. Pay has been constant all these while. 

Examples: 
New staff (just came in to work a week ago has given clearance for the next 2 weeks for leave) while existing staff has to plead her to approve our leave. 

Tone of talking to new staff VS old staff is very clear; very friendly and kind (even asking the young ladies out for desserts while old staff is treated like transparent, and having to do all the assigned work while the department head takes all of the new staff out).

Department head has a pet that bootlicks and buys dessert after every lunch. This staff is always at D.H. table for chit chat session, laughing super loudly while older staff works like a slave for the company (and yet effort is never recognised because of the D.H). 

Her "pet-dog" is always also given simple tasks, while D.H. delegates all the other work to me, and yet this pet always complains she is busy).

This makes work super unbearable, due to the unfair treatment.

review_title: Worst Job Experience ever, never join them
pros:
1 - Absolutely no care if you perform, so if you are lazy, sick all the time, you will be fine.
2 - Can play the gender or minority card and you can get a stable job without any results required.
3 - Great opportunities if you are fresh grads and fine to bring coffee to people who pretend working.
4 - Can come around 9h30am, do lunch break for 2 hours, go to gym for 1hour and finish around 5pm.
5 - As far as you suck up to 1 or 2 MD you don't need to speak to anyone below D-Level or in any other department as inclusivity is not meant for untermensch below VP level, you have the recreational club for that.
cons:
1 - Zero merit driven, it is pure politics and the right demographics,
2 - Management only trained to cut costs and have no clue about the market they service,
3 - Constant turn over of managers (in 5 years, I had 7 managers who had no clue of what they were doing),
4 - Zero Bonus
5 - Every quarter, witch hunt to fire your colleague sitting next to you, you can imagine the great team work environment
6 - Technology is all outsourced so you have thousands of applications/databases/intranets/MyDB and thousand of tools for the same purpose, but without any support.
7 - You re pretty much left by yourself, no-one has interest in helping each other anyway.
8 - The non-sense communication level is extreme: you will see opportunistic travels for young grads who are on the digitalisation or AI or virtual banking to attend useless conferences, whereas RTB team managers will have no opportunity to meet their team mates they have been working for 4years.
9 - You will work with dinosaurs who politically saved their jobs for the last 15years, so new joiners are only there to fix their urgent issue and go, not to become a new competitor in the survivor game.

review_title: Good place to start a career, but mediocrity quickly set in
pros: Decent pay to start off career & exposure as a graduate to systems, teams & processes. Generally quite friendly people in a co-operative & non-competitive / toxic environment.
cons:
Extremely poor technology & infrastructure - outdated software and hardware across the board. 
Getting access to systems can be a full time job of navigating 5+ different approvals and requests internal sites, each with little to no guides and layers upon layers of red tape. This made doing my job at times virtually impossible - which at least meant I had a good work life balance!

Beginning to enforce 3 day working in the office is terrible for employee retention - it may suit many directors who want to see their direct reports, but the same execs that harp on about collaboration never come to the floor to actually speak to the team instead preferring to stay cooped up in their offices.

review_title: Great place with desperate need of enhancements
pros: - Great Value & Believe culture - Great talents to work with - Cloud migration in progress, impressive momentum to learn and upgrade one's skills.
cons: a) Almost impossible to get promoted and many real talents leave London's offices for other companies offering better salary packages and titles. b) London's office is constantly reducing the number of people for cheaper locations (ex: India or east Europe) where less-talent people are getting hired with higher titles than deserved and better salary conditions (if compared to a lower cost of living). c) Technological devices provided to work are constantly under-performing and at the moment running meetings smoothly seems impossible.

pros:
Some incredible talent with staff set on course for intense redevelopment and discovery. There are many wonderful people in this organisation, and many of them are doing everything they can to reinvent and reboot banking from the inside. If you’re looking for a first job or place to build on your basic banking knowledge, then this is the opportunity you’ve been waiting for! 
Would recommend for grads and someone new to the industry. Also, if you’re terrible at your job, you should be able to find somewhere to hide in this organisation.
cons:
An incredibly top heavy organisation with plans to offshore everything but the vending machines. 
The long queue for the top, feels more like a slowly grinding treadmill, which only rewards a certain ethnic, gender mix. If you’re male and experienced, you’re likely to die before you’re promoted. Beyond that, you’re likely to be promoted before you receive a pay rise. Sadly, if you stay more than a year, you’ll be forced to watch many great people coming and leaving. This is a hard pill to swallow, whilst some of the longer standing untouchable staff languish in long periods of absenteeism and regularly miss “team” deadlines.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Dublin, Dublin
pros: - There's some fantastic people to collaborate with and learn from. - Nice new office -Great pension
cons: - Have completely ignored or failed to address the existence of the huge inflation we are all facing, almost all competitors have addressed this and reflected it in employee's remuneration. - Have a very rigid hybrid model of working with lots of red tape. - Performance related pay reviews not even up for discussion despite talent acquisition assuring me it would be an annual consideration. - Bonus is weak and the structures around it are opaque. - High turnover of staff and inability to hire quality replacements leading to increased burden on existing staff.

cons:
They never seem to fire or manage out those individuals who are incompetent. There is a culture of no accountability, no escalation from front office to infrastructure incompetence.

The board level management seems deaf to your average employee. Zero increase in base pay across infrastructure in a year of 10% inflation and the bank is making good revenues.

In the 2021 New York floods listening to Christiana say she hopes our basements are dry when many of us live in communities where people died in their flooded basements…that resonated badly with so many staff as how out of touch they are.

review_title: DB America good, DB Germany bad
pros: US investment bank colleagues are excellent and it has good leadership and culture. Great building in NY. Friendly and collaborative culture within the US.
cons:
The retail bank totally sucks and drags the rest of the bank down with it. There is a discount on what you can earn due to the IB bailing out the broken parts of the bank which they don't even want to fix as it is too political.

The IT is a horror show and there is no sign of them improving it (except for the IB platforms of course, which are strong).

Many (not all) German colleagues are often appointed due to their nationality and would never merit their role if it were a real meritocracy. The have no idea how bad they are, as Germany has no successful banks so in their context DB is the top of the mountain, but in reality, it is a very small mole hill when compared with US banks.

review_title: Generally a good environment, but lots of work politics and experience of bullying
pros: Joined as a graduate and the graduate scheme experience was excellent. I stayed for several years. Fantastic development opportunities initially, and there was a good culture with camaraderie in the team. Work felt rewarding and recognised, and there was a 'young' crowd.
cons:
'Younger' talent started leaving for competing banks and start ups. This left behind the less capable colleagues, which made it challenging.
A lot of politics around promotions and pay rises, which I feel fosters a toxic culture when it comes to the promotion time of year. No pay rise for 3 years consecutively.
Promotion is around who you know and who knows you, not what you deliver. Work can be unrecognised.
Atrocious experiences with managers and bullying which seems to be accepted as everyone passes this off as 'just their character'. Felt unsafe going through any HR grievance process and I resigned to take care of my mental health.

review_title: Generally a good place but some very mediocre colleagues and some dreadful decision making from MD level +
pros:
1) The base pay is OK-good and the health benefits and pension contributions are good-excellent. BUPA is the health provider and they were excellent. 

2) There are some fantastic colleagues who are really talented engineers. 

3) The offices are generally very pleasant. 

4) Some of the engineering work is really interesting and can be exciting.

5) If you get a good/supportive manager, you can boost your career growth in a shorter time span.
cons:
1) Is there ever a month that goes by in which Deutsche Bank isn't in the news for money laundering? It's demoralising working for an organisation that has a nefarious history and continues to be involved in dodgy activities. With the hundreds of millions spent on KYC processes at DB, it's incredible that such crimes continued to still occur very frequently. 

2) The resource planning that I witnessed was at times absolutely absurd. It got to the point where some teams were incredibly stretched working on key deliverables with tight deadlines and with a small team. And yet, DB hired external consultants on several ocassions who would be paid extortinate sums of money to come up with 'digital transformation' ideas that would be executed by DB engineers. So, the company is paying at least twice. That inconsistent approach to resourcing seemed to happen frequently. 

3) Some colleagues, especially around the VP level, are medicore and there's a layer of fat who enjoy good benefits which they realistically wouldn't get elsewhere who just stay and do just above the minimum while some really talented juniors get less benefits and tougher objectives. So, it's not really ultra meritocratic although if you really, really want it, you'll tend to get it. Also, at below VP level, no bonuses are paid. 

4) Also, the obsession from the senior management and board to get all employees, at least in Germany, COVID vaccinated and describing it as a 'moral obligation' in internal memos was creepy and a gross overreach. How about let employees decide for themselves what is best for their bodies or is that concept too hard for a German company to understand?

5) I experienced some super crazy politics that meant that collective objectives weren't met. At a VP+ level, things can become a bit machiavellian in that what's in the interests for the company aren't necessarily in the interests for your own personal career growth but that's an elephant in the room that everyone ignores. 

An example may be that a certain legacy system wasn't migrated to a new system because it has some critical functionality and the team supporting the application were fired very quickly in the past for some unknown reasons. By migrating the system and saving the company money, you wouldn't be able to have X budget to keep maintaining that sytem and having a bigger team. So, you would lose headcount and budget by doing what's a positive thing for the company. So objectives need to be better aligned. Also, teams would compete with each other for 'territory' as that would bring in more budget so things get quite odd when officially, you're in the same boat but unofficially, you're conspiring how to 'one up' them all the time. 

6) DB engineering tends to build things with the best of intentions and then some new top dog will come in and make wholesale changes, like firing an entire team that supports/maintains some applications, that make the past 2 years of hard work totally pointless and redundant. Technology and ways of doing things do indeed change but the lack of a consistent approach / consistent goal over different eras of Managing Directors results in a bit of a headless chicken effect.

7) It is getting much better but diversity at the top level is still lop-sided. There are measures being taken to address this but there's a long way to go.

Without a doubt, DB needs to focus on the basics - it's inexcusable that a bank of it's turnover and profit cannot put basic infrastrucutre in place and remove bureacracy - the people working here can't do their jobs as well so that'll hit the bottom line significantly.

pros:
Has some great people. The more recent the hired are the better.
The company is going through a "culture change" for the better.
There are opportunities for growth.
cons:
If you have any wealth coming in, even if you are not in a wealth management role or are in any position involving investments. Coming to work here will lock up assets. Trading will be restricted and can only have accounts in a select number of brokerages. - Liquidate to cash before coming on board. Their compliance only gives "yes"or "no" answers on trading in or out of positions. No information is given regarding why or when you can trade if they say "no." So one can get stuck with positions. 

Some of their established employees have attitudes - ie "Only Deutsche Bank people know how to do jobs 'right.' The rest of the world is stupid and does things incorrectly."

You won't get explanations from way to many older established employees. Just "not done right - do over." You either have to figure out yourself or reach out to an relatively new employee to get answers.


Oh - and the company is white white white white white... and I am a white guy.... Their diversity is weak. I've been involved in some interviews for new employees and heard form their longer established employees "I can't understand this potential employee because his/her accent is too harsh, I don't think he/she is capable of doing this job."
